commit_message: Fix Bioc version detection

Switch back to HISAT2 in Lamere Fig7 reproduction

HISAT2 is the most similar to Tophat among all the RNA-seq
quantification methods, so this should give the most direct
comparison.

Improve parametrization of RNA-seq file names

From the SummarizedExperiment stage on, we now always use
hg38.analysisSet as the genome name, even for HISAT2, where the
alignment was done against grch38_snp_tran, since the quantification
is done with the same reference as all the other quantification
methods. This simplifies the downstream file name handling, since we
don't have to handle the special case of HISAT2 using a different
genome name from all the other methods.

Remove unused R imports

This uses
https://gist.github.com/DarwinAwardWinner/ed75d6d845975a577c8533ac060d6d34
to find unused libraries, as well as the following R code to generate
perl commands to filter those libraries out of each file:

    library(rex)
    library(glue)
    x <- readRDS("~/Sync/pkg_usage.RDS")
    make_removal_regex <- function(pkgs) {
        rex(
            "library(",
            zero_or_more(space),
            or(pkgs),
            zero_or_more(space),
            ")")
    }
    removal_regexes <- x %>% lapply(. %$% Unused %>% setdiff("future")
    %>% make_remova    l_regex)
    glue("perl -iBAK -lane 'print unless m/'{shQuote(removal_regexes)}'/' scripts/{shQuote(names(removal_regexes))}")

Avoid loading params saved in rda files

Each Rmd file has an associated set of params, which gets saved along
with everything else when running save.image. This can clobber the
params of another Rmd file that loads the rda file saved from the
first Rmd script, unless steps are taken to prevent this from
happening.

Add a function for t-SNE to utilities.R

Major overhaul of ChIP-Seq workflow

Now the window size and fragment length for window counting are
parametrized. The window size has been changed from 150 to 500, since
the counts in 150-bp regions were too small to analyze effectively,
and also the number of small bins was bumping up against memory
limits. All the scripts from the window counting onward have been
substantially rewritten, and in particular the ChIP-Seq exploration
scripts have been split into a separate script for each histone mark,
allowing them to diverge, since an analysis that applies to one
histone mark may not apply to another.

Further refinements to RNA-seq Rmd files

The diff can't be cleanly separated into unrelated changes, but among
the changes are:

* Switch to using codingMatrices::code_control (plus some
  customizations) instead of contr.sum.
* Make a version of model.matrix that strips the factor names from the
  column names of the design matrix.
* Switch back to a non-parametric prior for ComBat, since including
  only technical batch (not donor) in the batches makes the parametric
  prior a worse fit.

Add a timeout to salmon command

The timeout is to counter the random indefinite hangs encountered:
https://github.com/COMBINE-lab/salmon/issues/111

Once this bug is resolved, the timout can be removed again.

Use the correct script for collecting shoal results

Also allow shoal to use up to 16 cores.

Render Rmd files in an external R session

rpy2 tends to munge the printed output or R code beyond recognition,
so now the workflow runs knitr in a new R process using Rscript. Now
the progress messages produced by knitr are readable again.
Use the correct libTypes
Rewrite BPtximport using bpvec

Use only BiocParallel for parallelism

This ensures that all parallel operations use the same backend.

This commit also add a better parallelization scheme for
featureCounts, using BiocParallel. The nthreads option to
featureCounts seems to have no effect on my system. Perhaps the file
I/O is the bottleneck or something. In any case, this now uses
BiocParallel to run featureCounts in a separate process for each file,
and then merge the results.

Allow ggprint to work with other print functions

Split SAM-to-BAM conversion into separate rule

The SAM-to-BAM conversion step for STAR is a single-core operation
that takes a while, but it was in the same rule as an 8-core
operation, meaning that 7 cores were wasted while it ran.

Fix an issue with idr input file processing

The idr script can only use the "score" column with an input file type
of bed, so even though the input from Epic is in narrowPeak format, we
tell idr that it's bed format (a subset of the columns in narrowPeak) in
order to use the score column. For consistency, all IDR output files for
both MACS2 and Epic now use the bed format.

Don't use oracle peak list for IDR

Since the oracle peak list is derived from 4 samples, using it to
compare just 2 samples causes issues since many of the top peaks could
be derived from the unused samples.
Update rulegraph

Overhaul IDR workflow

Vastly sped up and reduced memory usage by subsetting to only the top
150k peaks in each file.

Used the correct significance measure for each peak caller (i.e. the one
with the fewest repeated values).

Fix IDR handling of epic output format

The fix was to add a step converting the epic output file to narrowPeak
format and then use that for the IDR input.

Fix epic callpeak command, and other changes

The epic command included a "tail -f" in order to log to both a file and
stdout, but I forgot that "tail -f" doesn't know when the log file is
"done" and therefore never exits. In addition, I've added versions to
the IDR and CCF rules, and converted a bunch of log files to the "log:"
property instead of just making them another output file.

Avoid using STAR's bam sorting functionality

STAR's BAM sorter seems to be memory-limited with no facility to spill
over large BAM files to disk while sorting, so instead we use Picard.
